<<<code>>>: public class TestStringTokenStrict {

/**
 * Strict implementation of StringTokenizer
 * 
 * @param str
 * @param delim
 * @param strict
 *            true = include NULL Token
 * @return
 */
static StringTokenizer getStringTokenizerStrict(String str, String delim, boolean strict) {
StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(str, delim, strict);
StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer();
```csharp
while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
    String s = st.nextToken();
    if (s.equals(delim)) {
        sb.append(" ").append(delim);
    } else {
        sb.append(s).append(delim);
        if (st.hasMoreTokens())
            st.nextToken();
    }
}
return (new StringTokenizer(sb.toString(), delim));
```
}

static void altStringTokenizer(StringTokenizer st) {
while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
String type = st.nextToken();
String one = st.nextToken();
String two = st.nextToken();
String three = st.nextToken();
String four = st.nextToken();
String five = st.nextToken();
```scss
    System.out.println(
            "[" + type + "] [" + one + "] [" + two + "] [" + three + "] [" + four + "] [" + five + "]");
}
}

public static void main(String[] args) {
String input = "Record|One||Three||Five";
altStringTokenizer(getStringTokenizerStrict(input, "|", true));
}
}

<<<explanation>>>: The code you provided is not a valid Java code snippet. It appears to be a mixture of JavaScript and Java code.

To read a JavaScript array from a servlet in Java, you can use the `request.getParameterValues()` method to retrieve an array of strings. Here's an example:
```java
String[] data = request.getParameterValues("array[]");
```
This will retrieve an array of strings that were sent as part of the URL query string, with the name "array[]". You can then loop through the array and access each element using its index.

For example:
```java
for (int i = 0; i < data.length; i++) {
    String name = data[i];
    String url = // retrieve the value of the "url" parameter for the current element
    // do something with the name and url values
}
```
